choices.text: Complete abortion
Ectopic pregnancy
Incomplete abortion
Molar pregnancy

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to emergency with complaint of 2 months of amenorrhea with bleeding associated with passage of grape like clear vesicles. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Molar pregnancy

  • Grossly, complete moles have abnormal chorionic villi that appear as a mass of clear vesicles. These vary in size and often hang in clusters from thin pedicles.
  • The classic presentation of molar pregnancy is a h/o amenorrhoea with a positive UPT with bleeding with passage of typical grape like vesicles 

Other Options: 

Option A: Complete Abortion: Such a patient will present with a h/o amenorrhoea with a h/o bleeding and pain with passage of tissue but now she won't have any symotoms. On examination, the uterus is normal size and the os is closed. 

Option B: Ectopic Pregnancy: The classic triad of ectopic pregnancy is Abdominal pain + Amenorrhoea + Vaginal Bleeding. In a ruptured ectopic the patient will present with shock. 

Option C: Incomplete Abortion: Such a patient will present with heavy bleeding and pain abdomen with amenorrhoea. On examination, the uterus is less than the period of gestation. The os is open. 

Educational Objective: 

The classic presentation of molar pregnancy is a h/o amenorrhoea with a positive UPT with bleeding with passage of typical grape like vesicles ​​​​​​​

 

Ref: William’s obstetrics, 26th edition, chapter 13

choices.text: Complete abortion
Ectopic pregnancy
Incomplete abortion
Molar pregnancy

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents to emergency with 3 months amenorrhea and passage of vesicles as shown in image. The woman most likely has:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Molar pregnancy

  • The first image is the classical image of grape like vesicles seen in complete molar pregnancy
  • The second image is the HPE of complete molar pregnancy showing diffuse trophoblastic proliferation and diffuse villous edema

Other Options:

  • Option A: Complete abortion: This wont have any characteristic gross image unless it is > 12 weeks where fetal parts will be seen. On HPE there will be chorionic villi
  • Option B: Ectopic pregnancy: On HPE: chorionic villi will be seen
  • Option C: Incomplete abortion: This wont have any characteristic gross image unless it is > 12 weeks where fetal parts will be seen. On HPE there will be chorionic villi

Educational Objective: 

  • The first image is the classical image of grape like vesicles seen in complete molar pregnancy
  • The second image is the HPE of complete molar pregnancy showing diffuse trophoblastic proliferation and diffuse villous edema

 

Ref: William’s obstetrics, 26th edition, chapter 13

choices.text: Parvovirus infection
Partial mole
Rh incompatibility
Smoking in pregnancy

questions.text: A patient visits for ultrasound at 18 weeks, which shows fetus with syndactyly with multicystic placenta as shown below. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Partial mole

 

  • This is the ultrasound image of a partial hydatiform mole in which there are fetal parts (in this image the  the fetal head (arrow)) lies adjacent to an enlarged, multicystic placenta 
  • When fetus is present in conjunction with partial mole, it usually exhibits the stigmata of triploidy such as growth retardation, syndactyly and hydrocephaly.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Parvovirus infection in the fetus typically presents as fetal anemia and a hydropic fetus which appears as fetal ascites/ pericardial effusion/ pleural effusion/ scalp or skin edema and an enlarged placenta. A hydropic fetus appears as shown:

  • Option C: Rh iso-immunization: In severe fetal anemia, on ultrasound, a hydropic fetus will be seen as shown in the image above
  • Option D: Smoking in pregnancy: Smoking can increase the risk of cleft lip, palate, CNS and CVS anomalies. It is also associated with preterm borth, fetal growth restriction and fetal death. 

Educational Objective: 

  • On ultrasound an complete mole will have a snowstorm pappearance
  • A partial mole will have a cystic looking placenta with partial fetal parts seen

Ref: Berek and Novak, 16th edition, page 2762

William’s obstetrics, 26th edition, chapter 13,

choices.text: Ring of Pearls appearance
Rokitansky nodule
Snowstorm appearance
Waterlily sign

questions.text: Identify the ultrasound finding:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Snowstorm appearance

The mass is composed of numerous anechoic cystic spaces of different sizes and shapes, but without a fetus or amnionic sac. The appearance is often described as a “snowstorm”. Application of color Doppler displays marked surrounding myometrial vascularity. However, absent internal flow reflects the avascular villi of complete moles.

Other Options

  • Option A: String of pears appearance is seen in PCOS
  • Option B: Roktansky nodule is seen in Mature cystic teratoma or ovarian dermoid
  • Option D: Waterlily sign is seen in hydatid cyst

Educational Objective: 

  • Snowstorm appearance is characteristically seen in complete mole on ultrasound

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics, 26 edition, chapter 13.

choices.text: 46XX
46XY
69XXX
69YYY

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presented to emergency with 3 months pregnancy and bleeding per vaginum. She underwent suction evacuation for suspected molar pregnancy. Histopathology confirmed the diagnosis and showed scalloping of chorionic villi. The karyotype is likely to be:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 69 XXX

Scalloping of chorionic villi is suggestive of partial mole. Partial moles have triploid karyotype and amongst the triploid options the best answer is 69 XXX as 69YYY is non-viable gamete.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: 46XX: Partial moles are triploid and hence this is incorrect
  • Option B: 46XY: Partial moles are triploid and hence this is incorrect
  • Option D: 69 YYY: Although this is a triploid karyotype, 69YYY is a non viable gamete

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Partial moles are always TRIPLOD (69XXX/ 69 XXY)
    • 2 sperm fertilize one ova
    • The paternal contribution is called diandry
    • Hence both maternal and paternal component present in partial mole
    • Usually, 69XXX or 69XXY
  • Complete moles are DIPLOID
    • Formed by either 1 sperm fertilizing an empty/ inactivated ova and then undergoes duplication – this is called androgenesis OR 2 sperms (dispermy) fertilize an empty/ inactivated ovum 
    • 46XX or 46XY 
    • Only paternal component; No maternal component

Ref: Berek and  Novak 16 edition page 2764

choices.text: Chemotherapy
Hysterotomy
Suction evacuation
Uterine artery embolization

questions.text: A woman presents to emergency ward with 5 months of amenorrhea and bleeding PV, her fundal height is 18 weeks, but external ballotment is absent. USG shown snowstorm appearance. What is the best management option for her:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Suction evacuation

  • The description given is of a complete mole due to
    • H/o amenorrhea + bleeding
    • Absent external ballotment
    • Snowstorm appearance on ultrasound
  • The management of choice in a mplar pregnancy is suction and evacuation, irrespective of the uterine size.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Chemotherapy: This is given in gestational trophoblastic neoplasia and not in molar pregnancy.
  • Option B: Hysterotomy: There is no indication of doing a hysterotomy in molar pregnancy, Indications of hysterotomy are a failed medical 2nd trimester abortion
  • Option D: Uterine Artery Embolization: UAE is done in fibroid uterus, Adenomyosis, uterine AV malformation, placenta acrrete syndromes, PPH. It is not indicated in molar pregnancy. 

Educational Objective: 

  • The management of choice in a mplar pregnancy is suction and evacuation, irrespective of the uterine size.

 

Ref: berek and novak, 16th edition: page 2770

choices.text: CA 125
hCG
Inhibin A
PAPPA

questions.text: Which of the following marker is likely to be raised in molar pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. hCG

  • Beta hCG is a critical marker for GTD and its values are raised in molar pregnancy
  • Beta hCG is higher in complete moles (> 100,000) than partial mole

Other Options

  • Option A: Ca125: Ca125 is characteristically highly raised in epithelial ovarian cancers. It is also raised in pregnancy, fibroids, genital TB, PID, fibroids and endometriosis
  • Option C: Inhibin A: Inhibin A and B are raised in granulosa cell tumors of the ovary
  • Option D: PAPP-A: A low PAPP-A is associated with a higher incidence of Down syndrome in the fetus, increased risk of FGR, preeclampsia, preterm and fetal demise

Educational Objective: 

  • Beta hCG is a critical marker for GTD and its values are raised in molar pregnancy
  • Beta hCG is higher in complete moles (> 100,000) than partial mole

Ref: berek and novak, 16th edition: page 2757

choices.text: Absent in complete mole as it is maternal in origin
Absent in complete mole as it is paternal in origin
Present in complete mole as it is maternal in origin
Present in complete mole as it is paternal in origin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true in relation to P57 immunostaining in molar pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absent in complete mole as it is paternal in origin

  • p57KIP2 is a nuclear protein whose gene is paternally imprinted and maternally expressed.
  • This means that the gene product is produced only in tissues containing a maternal allele.
  • Because complete moles contain only paternal genes, the p57KIP2 protein is absent in complete moles, and tissues do not pick up this stain.
  • In partial moles as there is a maternal component, p57KIP2 is present

Educational Objective: 

  • p57KIP2 is a nuclear protein which is maternally expressed and hence present in partial moles (on immunohistochemstry) as partial moles have a maternal component
  • It is absent in complete moles

 

Ref: William’s obstetrics 26th edition, chapter 13.

choices.text: Fluid overload
Metastatic disease suggestive of GTN
Thyroid storm
Trophoblastic embolization

questions.text: A woman with molar pregnancy is undergoing suction evacuation. Suddenly she develops breathing difficulty, tachypnoea and fall in saturation. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Trophoblastic embolization

Trophoblastic Embolization

  • Respiratory distress sometimes occurs in patients with a complete mole.
  • It is usually diagnosed in patients with excessive uterine size and markedly elevated
  • These patients may have chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia and may experience severe respiratory distress during and after molar evacuation.
  • Auscultation of the chest usually reveals diffuse rales, and chest radiographic evaluation may show bilateral pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Respiratory distress usually resolves within 72 hours with cardiopulmonary support. In some circumstances, patients may require mechanical ventilation.

Other Options

  • Option A: Fluid overload can present similarly but is unlikely to happen in a suction evacuation. It is more common following hysteroscopic surgeries where excessive fluid gets absorbed leading to pulmonary edema
  • Option B: Metastatic disease suggestive of GTN. This usually would present post suction evacuation when the woman develps GTN. Lung metastases are common (canon ball mets) but this usually presents with cough. 
  • Option D: Thyroid storm is seen in complete molar pregnancy due to hyperthyroidism. This usually presents as  fever, marked tachycardia, heart failure, tremor, nausea and vomiting, diarrhea, dehydration, restlessness, extreme agitation, delirium or coma

Educational Objective: 

  • Respiratory distress sometimes occurs in patients with a complete mole.
  • It is usually diagnosed in patients with excessive uterine size and markedly elevated
  • These patients may have chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia and may experience severe respiratory distress during and after molar evacuation.
  • Auscultation of the chest usually reveals diffuse rales, and chest radiographic evaluation may show bilateral pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Respiratory distress usually resolves within 72 hours with cardiopulmonary support. In some circumstances, patients may require mechanical ventilation

Ref: Berek and Novak, 16th edition. 2767

choices.text: Curette
Karman cannula
Manual vacuum aspiration syringe
Pipelle suction curette

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Karman cannula

  • These are Karman cannulas
  • They are disposable plastic cannulas which are color coded depending on the diameter
  • They are used alongwith a Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) syringe to evacuate the products of conception (Suction and Evacuation) in the following scenarios
    • Surgical MTP < 12 weeks
    • Incomplete abortion
    • Inevitable abortion
    • Molar pregnancy

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Uterine curette appears as shown: 

  • Option C: MVA syringe: This is the apparatus in which the vacuum is created manually and the priducts of conception collect in the syringe (60 ml)

  • Option D: Pipelle biopsy cannula: This is a very thin disposable cannula used to take an office endometrial biopsy in women with AUB

 

Educational Objective: 

  • It is a plastic disposable cannula which ic color coded (based on the diameter)
  • It is used with the Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA) syringe to evacuate products of conception in
    • Surgical MTP < 12 weks
    • Incomplete abortion
    • Inevitable abortion
    • Molar pregnancy

 

Ref: Berek and Novak, 16th edition, page 2770

choices.text: No further follow up required
Till One more negative value 1 month later
Monthly follow up for 6 months
Monthly follow up for 1 year

questions.text: A woman underwent suction evacuation for complete mole. She was on weekly hCG follow up which has now returned to normal. What will be your advise to her for further follow up:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Monthly follow up for 6 months

  • Following evacuation of molar pregnancy, there is a risk of progression to choriocarcinoma and hence surveillance is done by checking the beta hCG levels. 
  • Post Evacuation Surveillance of molar pregnancy
    • Risk of progression to GTN is higher following complete mole (15%) than partial mole (5%)
    • Surveillance is done by serial measurement of β hCG to detect persistent/ renewed trophoblastic proliferation.
    • The initial baseline value is taken 2 days post evacuation 
    • Then weekly  beta hCGS are done till negative (This ususlaly takes 7 weeks for partial mole; 9 weeks for complete mole)
    • Once beta hCG is negative on weekly measurements, it is measured monthly for 6 months 

Educational Objective: 

  • Post Evacuation Surveillance of molar pregnancy
  • Risk of progression to GTN is higher following complete mole (15%) than partial mole (5%)
  • Surveillance is done by serial measurement of β hCG to detect persistent/ renewed trophoblastic proliferation.
  • The initial baseline value is taken 2 days post evacuation 
  • Then weekly  beta hCGS are done till negative (This ususlaly takes 7 weeks for partial mole; 9 weeks for complete mole)
  • Once beta hCG is negative on weekly measurements, it is measured monthly for 6 months 

 

Ref: FIGO cancer report, 2021

choices.text: No further follow up required
One more follow up 1 month later (if negative stop follow up)
Monthly follow up for 6 months, from date of evacuation
Monthly follow up for 6 months, from date of normalization

questions.text: A woman underwent suction evacuation and histopathology shows complete mole. She was kept on weekly hCG follow up. Her hCG returned to normal in 6 weeks. What is further plan for follow up:
questions.solution:
Ans. D . Monthly follow up for 6 months, from date of normalization

  • ollowing evacuation of molar pregnancy, there is a risk of progression to choriocarcinoma and hence surveillance is done by checking the beta hCG levels. 
  • Post Evacuation Surveillance of molar pregnancy
    • Risk of progression to GTN is higher following complete mole (15%) than partial mole (5%)
    • Surveillance is done by serial measurement of β hCG to detect persistent/ renewed trophoblastic proliferation.
    • The initial baseline value is taken 2 days post evacuation 
    • Then weekly  beta hCGS are done till negative (This ususlaly takes 7 weeks for partial mole; 9 weeks for complete mole)
    • Once beta hCG is negative on weekly measurements, it is measured monthly for 6 months 

Educational Objective: 

  • Post Evacuation Surveillance of molar pregnancy
    • Risk of progression to GTN is higher following complete mole (15%) than partial mole (5%)
    • Surveillance is done by serial measurement of β hCG to detect persistent/ renewed trophoblastic proliferation.
    • The initial baseline value is taken 2 days post evacuation 
    • Then weekly  beta hCGS are done till negative (This ususlaly takes 7 weeks for partial mole; 9 weeks for complete mole)
    • Once beta hCG is negative on weekly measurements, it is measured monthly for 6 months 

Ref: figo cancer report, 2021

choices.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
Recurrence of molar pregnancy
Relapse of Molar pregnancy
Trophoblastic embolization

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman underwent suction evacuation for molar pregnancy. Her hCG surveillance is as follows. What is the probable cause:

1 March: 200

7 March: 120

14 March: 900

21 March: 1300

28 March: 1700
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Box 1. FIGO criteria for diagnosis of postmolar gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Other Options

  • Option B and C: Recurrence of molar and relapse of molar: This is unlikely and would be called recurrence only if beta hCG touches normal and then she has another molar pregnancy
  • Option D: Trophoblastic embolization: This is a rare complication which can happen during evacuation of molar pregnancy and the patient presents with sudden carsiorespiratory arrest

Educational Objective: 

  • Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia should be suspected in a patient who has had a suction evacuation done followed by plateauing or increasing beta hCG levels OR of beta hCG persists even after 6 months of molar evacuation
  • If the question says that the beta hCG came to zero and again became positive, in such a scenario the 1st thing to think of is pregnancy

Ref: FIGO cnacer report 2021

choices.text: First trimester Abortion
Molar pregnancy
Term pregnancy
All of the above

questions.text: GTN can occur after:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

  • Gestational Trophophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) is most commnly seen after evacuation of a molar pregnancy (complete mole > partial mole). This accounts for about 50% of all GTN. 
  • As about 50% of GTN follows molar pregnancy, the rest can occur after a spontaneous abortion, ectopic pregnancy, or a term pregnancy.

Educational Objective: 

Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia can occur following Molar pregnancy (most commonly; complete mole > partial mole) but can also happen after a term/ preterm pregnancy or after an abortion or an ectopic pregnancy

Ref: FIGO cancer report 2021

choices.text: 3 months
6 months
1 year
2 years

questions.text: You have just completed the chemotherapy of GTN patient. How long will you ask her to follow up:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1 year

After treatment of a GTN, follow-up hCG monitoring every month for at least 12 months is essential for surveillance of relapse. Reliable contraception must be used throughout this period.

Future fertility, pregnancy, and offspring are not affected, although psychosocial and sexual counseling may be needed for some patients.

 

Ref: figo cancer report 2021
